name: Nanoscale Science and Engineering Center
html_description: Established by a grant from the National Science Foundation in 2001 under the direction of Professor Chad Mirkin, the NU-NSEC represents researchers from Northwestern University, University of Chicago, University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, and Argonne National Laboratory and their collaborators from industry, academic institutions, and national laboratories in the common goal to create an accelerated pathway from conception to application to commercialization.
additional_institutions: University of Chicago, University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, Argonne National Laboratory
sectors_facet: Biotech and Life Sciences,Healthcare and Medical Devices,Nanotechnology

name: Materials Research Science & Engineering Center
html_description: The NU-MRSEC maintains a number of shared facilities which provide faculty, students, and industrial partners with access to state-of-the-art equipment. Large facilities generally have on-site managers and regularly offer short courses on the use of the equipment.
sectors_facet: Nanotechnology

name: International Institute for Nanotechnology
html_description: Established in 2000, the International Institute for Nanotechnology (IIN) at Northwestern University is a global hub of excellence in the field and currently represents and unites over $600 million in nanotechnology research, educational programs, and supporting infrastructure. The IIN embodies an extraordinary combination of scientific capabilities, outreach programs, and partnerships that provide a unique and fertile ground from which to continue to make substantial contributions to the field and ensure that the U.S. remains a world leader in nanotechnology.
sectors_facet: Clean Tech/Alternative Energy,Food/Agriculture,Healthcare and Medical Devices,Nanotechnology

name: Nanotechnology Corporate Partners program
html_description: In today’s competitive business environment, industry often finds it necessary to cut back on R & D funding. Yet the need for a leading technological edge remains undiminished. University researchers and industry have critical resources to offer one another, and the Nanotechnology Corporate Partners program (NCP) creates that linkage. NCP participants benefit from ongoing multi-level interaction with faculty, staff, and students, thereby strengthening their relationships with one of the world’s leading centers for nanotechnology research. They gain exposure to a broad spectrum of applications and interact with a pool of highly talented and well-educated potential employees. As a member of the NCP program your organization receives a variety of participation options, allowing you to pursue those of greatest relevance to you.
sectors_facet: Nanotechnology

name: IIN Small Business Entrepreneur's Evaluation
html_description: The IIN's Small Business Entrepreneur's Evaluation (SBEE) program provides a platform for scientists and engineers to present their newly developed technologies and receive assistance in the development of viable business plans. Through this program, faculty members are offered the opportunity to present their marketable technology to an audience of students from the NU Kellogg School of Management, who then may use this as a springboard for writing a complete business plan. The success of the SBEE program is evidenced by the formulation of 20 start-up companies since the inception of the IIN who have raised over $700 million in venture capital to date
sectors_facet: Nanotechnology

name: Northwestern University Atomic and Nanoscale Characterization Experimental Center
resource_name: Northwestern University Atomic and Nanoscale Characterization Experimental Center
html_description: NUANCE Center integrates three existing complementary instrumentation facilities at NU: EPIC, NIFTI, and Keck-II under a unified management umbrella, and consolidated into contiguous space. These three facilities are a unique, centralized, resource for the NU community and beyond. NUANCE still retains the individual identity of the three facilities but their integration with unified operations permits synergy among instruments, staff, training, service and technical expertise.
sectors_facet: Biotech and Life Sciences,Nanotechnology

name: Nanoscale Integrated Fabrication, Testing, and Instrumentation (NIFTI)
resource_name: Nanoscale Integrated Fabrication, Testing, and Instrumentation (NIFTI)
html_description: NIFTI was created to drive interdisciplinary research bridging the gap between hard nanostructures, soft materials, biological sciences, quantitative mechanical and electrical analysis and nanopatterning. NIFTI provides a wide range of imaging instrumentation and support facilities for atomic to molecular imaging. It supports a broad range of nanoscale science and technology characterization needs at nanoscale by providing state-of-the-art resources coupled with expert staff. Research at NIFTI encompasses physical and chemical sciences, engineering and life sciences, and has a strong inter-disciplinary emphasis. Every week, several new users coming from NU campuses, academia, industry, and government laboratories learn to use tools available in the center to carry out their research projects.
sectors_facet: Biotech and Life Sciences,Nanotechnology

name: Electron Probe Instrumentation Center (EPIC)
html_description: EPIC is part of the Materials Research Science and Engineering Center (MRSEC) at Northwestern University, housing one of the most complete arsenals of routine and state-of-the-art electron microscopes in the world. EPIC houses the following instruments for scanning electron microscopy (SEM), transmission electron microscopy (TEM) including scanning transmission electron microscopy (STEM), focused-ion beam (FIB) and specimen preparation facility (SPF). EPIC jointly collaborates with the Quantitative Bioelemental Imaging Center core facility as well.
sectors_facet: Biotech and Life Sciences,Nanotechnology

name: Keck Interdiscplinary Surface Science Center
html_description: The Keck-II Center was established in late 2001 through the support of W. M. Keck Foundation. Keck-II also has received some support from Northwestern's Institute for Nanotechnology's NSF-sponsored Nanoscale Science & Engineering Center (NSEC) as well as from the State of IL and Northwestern University. Keck-II facilitates research, collaboration, education and outreach in all science from soft biological matter to hard physical matter, specializing in surface analysis and nano-scale characterization. Keck-II hosts Time-of-Flight Secondary Ion Mass Spectrometry (ToF-SIMS), X-ray Photoelectron Spectroscopy (XPS/ESCA), Fourier Transform Infrared Spectroscopy (FT-IR), Confocal Raman System, high resolution stylus profilometer, Spectroscopic Ellipsometer, and IR microscope. Keck-II is open to all the faculty and students at Northwestern University as well as the researchers at the nearby academic institutions and related industrial companies. The Keck-II Center operates and functions like its sister facilities (NIFTI and EPIC)-based on the core philosophy of open-access, hand-on training, collaboration and assistance from our able staff. Training is offered on a periodic basis, both as “crash courses” or part of hands-on structured courses, as well as individual ad-hoc training as need arises.
sectors_facet: Biotech and Life Sciences,Nanotechnology

name: Micro/Nano Fabrication Facility (NUFAB)
html_description: NUFAB is an advanced micro/nano fabrication research facility at Northwestern University. It provides resources for research in MEMs/NEMs, nano-bio, nano/microelectronics, and other related and interdisciplinary areas to Northwestern University community and outside researchers. NUFAB currently resides in EG20-NG32 Technological Institute and has all new research equipment. Please check the equipment list at http://nufab.northwestern.edu/equipment. In July 2013, it will relocate to a new clean room facility. Many more new research tools will be added at that time.
sectors_facet: Biotech and Life Sciences,Nanotechnology

name: Institute for BioNanotechnology in Medicine
html_description: The Institute for BioNanotechnology's (IBNAM) mission is to combine the expertise of faculty members from Northwestern's Feinberg School of Medicine, McCormick School of Engineering and Applied Sciences, and Weinberg College of Arts and Sciences in a collaborative environment and to foster cross-disciplinary research initiatives that cannot take place in isolation. IBNAM especially aims to promote translational bionanotechology research that has the potential to revolutionize regenerative medicine and produce targeted therapeutics. The institute performs research in fields that can have profound impacts on regenerative medicine and targeted therapeutics, such as self-assembly, tissue engineering, genomics, smart drug delivery, and developing new bionanotechnologies. IBNAM faculty members work on developing tools for detecting and treating cancer, reversing paralysis due to spinal cord injury, regenerating vital organs, repairing the vascular system, and developing targeted therapeutics for dreaded diseases such as Alzheimer's, atherosclerosis, diabetes, and Parkinson's.
sectors_facet: Biotech and Life Sciences, Healthcare and Medical Devices, Nanotechnology

name: Center for Molecular Innovation and Drug Discovery
resource_name: Center for Molecular Innovation and Drug Discovery
html_description: The Center for Molecular Innovation and Drug Discovery provides a collaborative research platform that brings together biologists and synthetic and medicinal chemists and enables the translation of basic scientific discoveries into potential new therapeutics.
sectors_facet: Biotech and Life Sciences

name: Chemistry of Life Processes Institute
html_description: Breaking from traditional single-discipline methodology by fostering collaboration among a broad spectrum of scientists, the Chemistry of Life Processes Institute (CLP) transcends conventional intellectual and physical boundaries to generate new horizons of discovery. An “institute without walls,” the CLP provides the infrastructure necessary to help articulate and explore emerging research questions across the disciplines of physics, chemistry, biology, engineering, medicine, and computational science. The Institute’s role in promoting scientific discovery is shaped by the fundamental recognition that established institutional boundaries must be transcended to produce transformative scientific advances. Proceeding from the premise that interdisciplinary approaches to science can generate these advances in ways that traditional, single-discipline methodology cannot, CLP fosters collaborative research at the interface of the chemical, physical, engineering, and life sciences. In providing the organizational philosophy, administrative structure, and physical environment necessary to sustain these cross-disciplinary collaborations, the Institute reduces barriers that typically impede major scientific discoveries. And by uniting scholars from disparate disciplines to investigate emerging research questions that require the formulation of new paradigms and the application of novel methods, CLP also creates the conditions necessary for a new wave of scientific innovation on the Northwestern campus. CLP’s catalytic role in the discovery process will be complemented by a parallel endeavor to maximize the beneficial impact of its findings through translational research. The centerpiece of this effort will be the implementation of an Integrated Program for Molecular Therapeutics, which will provide a pipeline linking drug discovery to pre-clinical testing by capitalizing on the Institute’s established clinical partnerships and key strengths in high throughput screening, imaging, and proteomics. Accelerating the translation of scientific discoveries from the laboratory bench to the patient bedside, this entrepreneurially-oriented program will help the Institute transcend yet another entrenched barrier—the divide separating dynamic academic research from the marketplace, and by extension, from populations who will benefit from creative solutions to existing limitations in medical treatment. The Chemistry of Life Processes Institute establishes relationships with corporations and foundations to secure funding for projects of mutual interest.
sectors_facet: IT/Digital/Web-Mobile, Biotech and Life Sciences, Healthcare and Medical Devices, Nanotechnology

name: Polsky Center for Entrepreneurship and Innovation
address: Polsky Center for Entrepreneurship at The U of C Booth School of Business
resource_name: Polsky Center for Entrepreneurship and Innovation
html_description: The Polsky Center for Entrepreneurship and Innovation at the University of Chicago advances the knowledge and practice of entrepreneurship and innovation. The center is the hub of entrepreneurship, private equity, and venture capital activity for the university. It supports entrepreneurial learning and collaboration through its cutting-edge curriculum, innovative hands-on learning experiences, leading faculty research, conferences, mentorship, and community and global outreach programs. The Polsky Center works closely with students, alumni, and others from the UChicago network and across the city/state/country, providing educational opportunities (which focus on topics ranging from marketing to business development). While there are no fees to use the Polsky Center, many of our programs are available to students who must pay tuition, and many of our conferences require registration fees. The Center is open to the public, however, we primarily serve current students and alumni of the University of Chicago. Our website and calendar outline which programs and resources are limited and open to the public.

name: Exploring Entrepreneurship Conference Series
address: Polsky Center for Entrepreneurship at The U of C Booth School of Business
html_description: As part of the Donald W. Hamer, '58, Small Business Initiative, the Polsky Center launched the Exploring Entrepreneurship Series in 2006 to examine specific industries that are key to the economic growth of the region. Through this program, students, faculty, alumni, and members of the regional business community are brought together to study both the challenges and opportunities facing an industry's ability to grow and maintain leadership. The series has focused on the education industry (2010), the food industry (2009), and the futures trading industry (2006).

name: National Center for Supercomputing Applications
html_description: The National Center for Supercomputing Applications (NCSA), located at the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, provides powerful computers and expert support that help thousands of scientists and engineers across the country improve our world. With the computing power available at NCSA, researchers simulate how galaxies collide and merge, how proteins fold and how molecules move through the wall of a cell, how tornadoes and hurricanes form, and other complex natural and engineered phenomena. NCSA—established in 1986 as one of the original sites of the National Science Foundation's Supercomputer Centers Program—is supported by the state of Illinois, the University of Illinois, the National Science Foundation, and grants from other federal agencies. For 25 years, NCSA has been a leader in deploying robust high-performance computing resources and in working with research communities to develop new computing and software technologies. Building on this history of leadership, NCSA and its partners are at work on the Blue Waters project, which will provide the national research community with a sustained-petaflop supercomputer. NCSA also leads the National Science Foundation's Extreme Science and Engineering Discovery Environment, a five-year, $121 million project to deliver advanced computing, data, networking, and collaboration tools and support to the nation's researchers.
sectors_facet: IT/Digital/Web-Mobile, Biotech and Life Sciences, Nanotechnology, Telecommunications

name: Beckman Institute for Advanced Science and Technology
resource_name: Beckman Institute for Advanced Science and Technology
html_description: The Beckman Institute at Illinois is a world-class interdisciplinary facility devoted to ground-breaking research in the physical sciences, computation, engineering, biology, behavior, cognition, and neuroscience. The Institute's primary mission is to foster interdisciplinary work of the highest quality, transcending many of the limitations inherent in traditional university organizations and structures. The Institute was founded on the premise that reducing the barriers between traditional scientific and technological disciplines can yield research advances that more conventional approaches cannot.

name: Illinois Simulator Laboratory
html_description: Virtual Reality simulators, including but not limited to a full-car driving simulator, flight simulator, motion capture suite, and immersive visualization CAVE. Research is accepted through the normal funding mechanisms of the Beckman Institute at the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign.
facilities_facet: Research Center/Facilities, Research Equipment, Testing Services

name: Biomedical Imaging Center
html_description: BIC is home to a wide variety of research programs, providing facilities, equipment, and training for research on nuclear magnetic resonance imaging and spectroscopy. The Center's goal is to conduct research and develop MRI technology that addresses questions ranging from the single cell to the complex inter-dependent systems underlying cognitive function. BIC is committed to the development of cutting edge techniques which integrate magnetic resonance methods with other imaging techniques, including optical imaging, eye-tracking, EEG and MEG. Four imaging modalities are supported: magnetic resonance imaging, ultrasound imaging, micro PET/SPECT/CT imaging, and diffuse optical imaging. For more details on the equipment, see http://bic.beckman.illinois.edu/resources.html. There are hourly fees associated with each imaging modality. The resource is available to organizations outside of UIUC through the use of a University Technical Testing Agreement or through collaborative grants from Federal, State, or private foundation funding sources.
region_facet: Statewide, Central Illinois, Midwest Region, Nationwide
sectors_facet: Biotech and Life Sciences, Healthcare and Medical Devices

name: ITG Visualization Laboratory
html_description: The Visualization Laboratory (Vis Lab) is a high-end graphics computer-based facility designed to support the computational needs of ITG’s users. Resources include instrumentation for data capture, including 2D (high-resolution, optically accurate scanners for film, histology slides, and other materials; digital still SLR and quasi-SLR cameras; HD/SD digital and analog professional video cameras for capturing time-variant data) and 3D (contact- and optics-based 3D scanners for capturing the surface shape and texture of physical objects). The video production facilities include HD-capable editing systems, providing scientists with the ability to acquire, process, record, and create both digital video and audio. High-end workstations (Intel or AMD multi-core/64-bit with 12GB+ RAM, ultra-fast 3D graphics, striped RAID local online storage, etc.) running Windows 7 Enterprise, Mac OS, and Linux support a wealth of software resources for 2D quantitative image analysis, volumetric data analysis, molecular simulation, data visualization, 3D modeling/animation, and scientific computing. The Vis Lab is supported by a full-time manager to train and work with users in the facility. The Vis Lab and all equipment resources are accessible 24 hours a day, every day of the year. A specialized team of graphic artists and photographers are also available to create images, animations, and videos for publications and research presentations. Visualization resources include powerful computer workstations with the latest high-end 3D software packages to support imaging research. These computer workstations provide a next-step for researchers conducting analysis, image processing, and 3D/4D reconstruction of their image data. Software applications that might otherwise be cost-prohibitive for a single investigator’s lab are maintained in this centralized facility. Current imaging software in the Vis Lab includes Visage Imaging Amira, Bitplane Imaris, COMSOL Multiphysics, Image-Pro Plus, Maya, ZBrush, Rhino, RealFlow, Geomagic, Adobe Creative Suite Master Collection, many open-source imaging applications, and a variety of other useful imaging packages. In addition to computer hardware and imaging software, imaging modalities and support equipment in the Vis Lab include macro-photography (Canon 1Ds Mark III DSLR camera, 5D Mark II & III, TMC vibration isolation table, complete suite of Canon SLR lenses, and professional lighting equipment), high-definition video is possible with the 5D cameras, high definition 3D laser surface scanning (Steinbichler L3D for ultra-resolution, 3D3 Systems for mid-resolution, and NextEngine HD 3D Desktop Scanner for low resolution parts), 2D scanning (Nikon LS-9000 slide/film scanner, Epson 10000RXL 11"x17" flatbed scanner, Epson Perfection V700 professional photo flatbed scanner) multimedia production (video and animation studio equipment).

name: Imaging Technology Group (ITG) Microscopy Suite
html_description: The Microscopy Suite provides researchers with four basic modes of imaging, with attendant spectroscopies, the requisite sample preparation equipment, and other capabilities and research aids, as well as a cell-and-tissue-culture facility: light microscopy, scanned probe microscopy, electron microscopy, and X-ray computed tomography. The Wet Lab includes a dual-metal evaporator, two sputter coaters, a glow-discharge unit, and a critical point dryer. Also available in the Microscopy Suite are two lightscattering particle sizers (one with zeta potential), covering the range from 1 nm to 20 micrometers; a carbon evaporator; a plasma asher; a spin coater; and an ultramicrotome, as well as many other smaller items. Fees are listed on the web page: http://itg.beckman.illinois.edu/microscopy_suite/fees/. The facility is available to researchers in the University of Illinois system, researchers from outside of the University of Illinois system, and researchers with US Military or Industry affiliations. For anyone outside of the University of Illinois system, agreements (facility user agreement or technical testing agreement, generally) are required.
region_facet: Statewide, Northeast Illinois-Chicagoland Region, Northwest Illinois, Southeast Illinois, Southwest Illinois, Central Illinois, Midwest Region, Nationwide
sectors_facet: MultiDisciplinary Facility
additional_info: The Microscopy Suite provides researchers with four basic modes of imaging, with attendant spectroscopies, the requisite sample preparation equipment, and other capabilities and research aids, as well as a cell-and-tissue-culture facility. 1) Light microscopy includes a Zeiss inverted fluorescence microscope with a version of SIM (structured illumination microscopy) that can perform tiling in x, y, and z, plus a high-quantum-efficiency EMCCD camera for  imaging weak fluorescence; a stereology workstation based on a Zeiss standard-body microscope, with fluorescence capability, transmitted and reflected light capability, and high-precision x,y,z control that meshes with the MBF Biosciences StereoInvestigator and Neurolucida software; two Leica SP2 confocal microscopes with (between them) laser lines at 458, 476, 488, 514, 543, and 633 nm, plus UV (350 nm); a sophisticated Zeiss SteREO zoom dissecting microscope with a high-speed video camera and a high-resolution color camera, among others; a Zeiss inverted microscope with UV/Vis, Near IR, and Raman spectroscopy capability, with an x,y,z stage that enables line scans; a Horiba LabRAM HR confocal Raman imaging system with 532-, 633-, 785-, and 830-nm lasers plus transmitted light capability, strain/tensile-testing capabilities, and heavy-duty and hot/cold stages, among other options; plus a Nikon confocal microscope with two-photon/multiphoton/single-photon capability set up with TIRF, FLIM, and FCS. 2) Scanned probe microscopy includes a Bruker 5k x 5k AFM with ten wide-bandwidth channels, a separate Bioscope setup for imaging cells in Petri dishes, a NanoFactory STM-in-a-TEM holder for the TEM, and an NSOM system with fiber/micropipette puller and dedicated aluminum evaporator. 3) Electron microscopy includes a Philips/FEI CM200 TEM with double-tilt holder, standard holder, the STM-in-a-TEM holder, a high-tilt holder that permits 70- to 80-degree tilt capability for which the TEM was custom-ordered, a strain holder, and a bulk/STM/AFM tip holder, with a 2k x 2k digital camera, as well as a Philiips/FEI XL30 ESEM-FEG environmental scanning electron microscope with EDS, hot stages, Peltier stage, and a number of other options. 4) X-ray computed tomography includes a Skyscan MicroCT with a strain/tensile stage and 5-micrometer resolution, an Xradia MicroCT with 700-nm resolution, an Xradia Bio MicroCT with 700-nm resolution and the ability to (e.g.) image fuel cells while they are running, and an Xradia NanoCT system with 50-nm resolution. The Wet Lab includes a dual-metal evaporator, two sputter coaters, a glow-discharge unit, and a critical point dryer. Also available in the Microscopy Suite are two lightscattering particle sizers (one with zeta potential), covering the range from 1 nm to 20 micrometers; a carbon evaporator; a plasma asher; a spin coater; and an ultramicrotome, as well as many other smaller items.

name: Academy for Entrepreneurial Leadership
html_description: The Academy for Entrepreneurial Leadership at the University of Illinois offers entrepreneurship programs, services and resources to faculty, students and community members. The Academy’s mission is to encourage entrepreneurial awareness and initiatives across all disciplines at the University. Drawing on the strengths of all fields across the Illinois campus, AEL helps to initiate, build and connect an understanding, appreciation and inclusion of entrepreneurship.

name: Technology Entrepreneur Center
html_description: Created in 2000 to highlight the University’s rich history and culture of innovation, TEC continues to inspire its students to become the next generation of world-changing visionaries, leaders and entrepreneurs. This is accomplished through its courses, venture and product competitions, workshops and other curricular and extra-curricular events that expose students to the complex concepts inherent in the simultaneous processes of technology innovation and market adoption. TEC offers on-site and online certificate programs for education and professional development and hosts outreach activities for students and alumni. TEC also administers the annual V. Dale Cozad New Venture Competition and the $30,000 Lemelson-Illinois Student Prize for innovation, among several other programs.

name: Cozad New Venture Competition
html_description: The Cozad New Venture Competition (CNVC) is designed to encourage students, researchers, and community members to create new sustainable businesses. Teams are invited to create a venture around a topic of their choice. The competition process offers teams assistance in the form of: mentors to help guide them through the phases of venture creation, workshops to help with idea validation, pitching skills, customer development, and more as well as and courses to enhance their skills and knowledge. Teams who make it to the final rounds of competition will have the opportunity to meet with venture capitalists, early stage investors and successful entrepreneurs who will serve as judges for the finals round. The judges will determine up to 10 finalist teams that will present their ventures at the finals event. These teams will compete for an estimated $50,000 in cash, plus valuable in-kind prizes.

name: Office of Technology Management
html_description: Since its founding in 1867, the University of Illinois has earned a reputation of international stature. Our distinguished faculty, outstanding resources, and depth of research disciplines all contribute to a world-class institution. At the Office of Technology Management, our purpose is to provide responsive, professional services to ensure the results of this research are successfully transferred outside the university to drive economic growth in the State of Illinois and benefit the general public. Our external audience are those companies or individuals who seek access to University of Illinois intellectual property to build companies, develop products and services or the like.

name: I-Start program
html_description: The I-Start Entrepreneur Assistance Program is a matching award program targeted to University of Illinois researchers that have a strong potential for technology commercialization through new company formation. I-Start offers a suite of first-year professional services startup services for new University of Illinois entrepreneurs including business development, legal setup, SBIR application, bookkeeping assistance, and marketing assistance. EnterpriseWorks has referrals to providers that can offer the scope of services at rates that match the funding level. We competitively award companies between 50-90% of the cost of the services (no equity is taken). The EIR help evaluate these clients and monitor their progress.

During each engagement, companies, educators, experts and students collaborate on real world problems and deliver real world results. The Innovation Center is a community of industry entrepreneurs and academic researchers working in partnership to instigate breakthroughs: fusing the uncommon, taking risks, thinking big.

resource_name: NMR Facility at the Department of Medicinal Chemistry and Pharmacognosy
html_description: NMR services are available to the general public. Please contact Dr. Alec Krunic to discuss your needs and inquire about external user rates. Facility personnel are available to assist with sample runs and/or experimental design.

additional_info: 1) 400 MHz Bruker DPX-400 NMR spectrometer equipped with a 5 mm QNP (4-nucleus) probe for 1H, 13C, 19F and 31P observation. The probe is switchable between nuclei using a software controlled switching box. Most of the NMR experiment run on this instrument, including gradient selected 2-D experiments, can be run in a manual or semi-automatic mode. This instrument is also equipped with an auto-sampler which allows unattended operation of up to 60 samples. This probe is also equipped with a variable temperature unit which is capable of operation in the range of -150ÁC to + 200ÁC. The host computer (PC) is currently running XWIN-NMR v. 3.1 software.2) 400 MHz Bruker AVANCE-400 spectrometer equipped with a 5mm ATM (auto frequency tune and match) probe which allows automatic frequency tuning and impedance match on the decouple channel (1H) as well as the broad band (BB) observe channel (31P to 109Ag). Most of the NMR experiments run on this instrument, including gradient selected 2-D experiments and selective 1-D experiments, can be run in a manual or semi-automatic mode. The ATM probe is equipped with a variable temperature unit which is capable of operation in the range of +35ÁC to +200ÁC. The host computer (PC) is running XWIN-NMR v. 3.5 software.The AVANCE console described above is equipped with gradient amplifiers and digital shaped pulse generator for selective excitation. Non-gradient versions of the 2-D experiments are also available. Bruker most recent TopSpin software v1.3, for acquisition and processing of NMR data, will be available soon. The system also features updated BACS-60 auto sampler for unattended runs.

name: Microphysics Laboratory, Department of Physics
html_description: The Microphysics Laboratory (MPL) at the University of Illinois at Chicago (UIC) is currently the only university laboratory in the U.S. performing fundamental research on mercury cadmium telluride (MCT), grown by molecular beam epitaxy (MBE). It has been involved in this field since its inception in the early 1980s. It is a center for basic and applied physics research with an emphasis on II-VI materials and devices for infrared sensing and imaging and for the development of multijunction II-VI photovoltaic cells. Since 1982, MPL has been awarded over $30 million in external research support to facilitate the development of high-quality night vision and of photovoltaic technology. Dr. Sivalingam Sivananthan has been the director of MPL since 1994 and has worked in semiconductors and infrared and night vision detector technology for many years. He has helped to pioneer the development and fabrication of the now-dominant high-end infrared detecting/night vision semiconductor material, MCT. MPL’s research is focused on the optimization of the MBE growth of MCT, the study of in-situ/ex-situ doping and transport, and the growth of high-quality, alternative, composite CdTe/Si substrates to be used for the growth of large area MCT. MPL’s fundamental research activities have resulted in the education of highly qualified and trained MCT scientists, who have transferred the lab’s knowledge base and traditions of excellence to the industry and government research agencies, such as the U.S. Army Night Vision Laboratory, the U.S. Army Research Laboratory, DRS Technologies, Northrop Grumman, and Teledyne Scientific & Imaging. MPL consists of faculty, research members, students and staff. Currently eight graduate and three undergraduate students are working on-site and off-site on various research projects and thesis topics. In order to be able to have access to use these instruments at MPL, pre-qualified users, whose pre-qualifications will be evaluated and determined by senior research staff, need to go through proper trainings by MPL research personnel and take UIC's online safety trainings given by the Dept of EHSO at UIC. Please contact Dr. Sivananthan for MBE Chamber Access Fees. Discounted rates are available for monthly, quarterly and annual access.
facilities_facet: Research Center/Facilities, Research Equipment, Testing Services
sectors_facet: Clean Tech/Alternative Energy, Manufacturing, Biotech and Life Sciences, Nanotechnology
additional_info: Microphysics Laboratory Facility Information, Equipment and Other Resources:1) II-VI growth and in situ characterization facilities The MPL at the UIC maintains four RIBER MBE growth systems; a 3-inch Riber 32P MBE system, two Riber 2300 system, and a 5-inch Riber Opus system. These four machines offer great flexibility in the range of materials grown and in the in situ characterization techniques available to the grower. The Riber 32P MBE system is configured for the growth of HgCdTe layers and superlattices. This chamber is equipped with a valved Hg cell and an indium cell for n-type doping. It is also equipped with a state-of-the-art Woollam M2000 Spectroscopic Ellipsometer capable of in situ measurement of the dielectric function of the growing surface in the spectral range of 0.7 to 5.0 eV. Two Riber 2300 systems are configurable for the growth of various materials including wide band II-VI and thin magnetic layers. Finally, the Riber Opus system is primarily configured for the growth of CdTe on large (up to 5 inch) Si substrates. The in situ characterization techniques attached to the four growth chambers include RHEED, spectroscopic ellipsometry, XPS and AES. A clean room which is constructed following the Federal Standard 209e Class 10K, contains all MBE chambers as well as three complete chemical hoods for sample preparation. In addition, MPL also has a RF magnetron sputtering system, several thermal evaporation systems, as well as sol-gel and chemical deposition facilities for poly-crystalline or nano-scale crystalline film deposition or growth.  2) Ex situ characterization facilities Electrical characterization facilities in MPL include Hall effect and other current-voltage measurement equipment (fully automated from 300 K down to 8 K). This equipment can be upgraded in order to perform photonic-electrical-magnetic measurements to determine carrier diffusion lengths and recombination lifetimes. It can also perform I-V device characterization measurements from 8 K to room temperature. Bruker D8 Discover High resolution X-ray diffraction System with Ge 4-bounce monochrometer and Ge 3-bounce path finder to measure crystal rocking curve (RC) FWHMäó»s of the epitaxial layers. It was supported by ARO though its 2008 DURIP program.Research class step scan Nicolet 870 FTIR spectrometer operable at wave lengths between 500 nm in the visible to 200 µm in the VLWIR with variable temperature capability from 1.9 to 300 K. The instrument is capable of performing double modulation spectroscopic measurements of spectral response and relative quantum efficiency of devices. This instrument can measure transmission, reflection and the spectral response of photocurrent at the same position on the sample.  In addition, MPL ex-situ characterization lab includes:¥_ Infrared microscope mapping to analyze composition and thickness uniformities with a lateral resolution of 1 µm/step and a focus with a diameter of 20 µm.¥_ I-V and C-V device characterization equipment operable in the range of 77-300 K.¥_ Temperature-dependant photoconductive decay lifetime equipment capable of operating in the range 77-300 K.¥_ M2000 Spectroscopic ellipsometry equipment¥_ Scanning probe microscope that can measure AFM under both contact and tapping mode for the samples with ä_ 4 inch diameters.¥_ Device detectivity measurements.  3) Device fabrication facilities The device fabrication clean-room laboratory, which was assembled in September, 2004, houses a variety of instruments that users can use for photolithography, fabrication, metal-bump hybridization and back-end.The lithography capabilities include a Karl Suss MJB3 mask aligner for 'top to bottom' alignment of masks to wafers. It can accommodate samples ranging in size from a few millimeters to two inches (5.08 cm). The system can deliver accuracy up to 0.8 um. The alignment module is capable of handling proximity, soft contact and high precision (vacuum) printing requirements. The thin film deposition capabilities consist of four thermal evaporation chambers for ZnS, CdTe, wax and thick In-bump metal and a 4 pockets e-beam metal deposition system for Au, Ni, Cu and Ti, which allows depositing of metal films for contacts or depositing insulating films of CdS. The sputtering system also has been operated in either DC or RF mode for dielectrics and metals.A diamond stylus surface profilometer (XP-1, Ambios) has been used to measure small surface variations in vertical stylus displacement as a function of position.The hybridization area consists of a thermosonic ball bonder (4525, K&S) and Flip Chip Aligner Bonder (M-8G, Research Devices, Inc.), which can easily accommodate different sizes of chips for bonding to various types and sizes of substrate and expand up to 512x512 IRFPAs structure. The dicing saw/cutting saw (982-6, K&S) which uses a high speed (25000 äóñ 30000 rpm) rotating ultra-thin diamond impregnated blade, in a wet environment, to cut or grove materials such as silicon wafers, glass sheets, ceramic, etc."------------------------MBE Chamber Access Fees                           Unassisted/Daily                          Assisted/DailyUIC                           $450 name: Office of Technology Management
html_description: UIC ranks among the nation's leading research universities, a place where outstanding faculty, staff, and students come together to further the pursuit of scientific understanding and innovation. The Office of Technology Management’s mission is to encourage that innovation, enhance research and facilitate economic development through the effective management, transfer, and commercialization of UIC technologies and intellectual property. Our focus is on ensuring the results of the outstanding research at UIC are successfully transferred outside the University to drive economic growth in the State of Illinois and benefit the general public. Resources available through the UIC Office of Technology Management include the Proof of Concept (POC) Gap Initiative Funding Program to help bridge the gap between basic research funding and commercialization and the Chicago Innovation Mentors (CIM) program which is a multi-institution initiative that cultivates university technology commercialization by matching experience entrepreneurs, executives and domain experts with innovating faculty members. Intellectual property developed at UIC is available for licensing to the general public through the Office of Technology Management. Proof of Concept (POC) Gap Funding, Chicago Innovation Mentors and general support around intellectual property matters is available to UIC faculty and students.

name: Innovation and New Ventures Office
html_description: The Innovation and New Ventures Office inspires and nurtures a culture of innovation, bridging Northwestern research with its practical use for public benefit. We scout for research that could have commercialization potential and provide guidance on how to maximize the impact of the innovations to society. Business development activities at INVO coordinate with entrepreneurial and innovation initiatives across all schools within Northwestern. Our goal is to enhance the value and impact of the invention by facilitating alliances, to further technology validation and possibly to increase funding. Business development culminates in the drafting of a commercial plan. The business development team promotes broad dissemination of the inventions through an extensive corporate and investor network. Our Investor Advisory Board composed of investors, entrepreneurs and business executives oversees all activities and provides financial and management mentorship. Northwestern protects and manage the inventors' and the University's intellectual property rights through the licensing division of INVO. Each invention is assigned a invention manager who coaches the inventor during the various phases - invention disclosure, determination of patentability, licensing negotiations and intellectual property management.

name: Office of Research Services
html_description: The new Office of Research Services contains the offices responsible for all public external funds (formerly OSPR), including pre and post- award personnel.  It also includes the research protections group (formerly ORP).  In the past year, we have reshuffled personnel and changed responsibilities to include a small group whose charge is to work on grants compliance policies as well as a separate group to work on Research Development and outreach. Research Development and Pre Award:	Responding to the continuously evolving needs of both investigators and funding agencies has defined the services and goals of the Pre-award Services unit of the Office of Sponsored Programs and Research.  The functions associated with this activity typically encompass every aspect of a research project, from assistance in articulation of a concept to providing operational support throughout the lifecycle of a proposal.  More specifically, pre award provides assistance in the identification of funding sources, interpretation of Request for Proposals (RFP), budget development, and in proposal development including consultation and coordination of interdisciplinary and inter-University projects and facilitating the process of proposal submission to external funding agencies.  	The Research Development activities are centered on creating a more vibrant Scholarly Community and enhancing the role of research.  Rather than focus on funding, their charge is to provide research support and outreach to the DePaul community.  This can be individual, departmental or College-level support.  Examples of these activities might include creating a long-term research plan and a funding plan to go with it; it might be a workshop on how to balance research with teaching a service, or it could be a grant-writing workshop.  Post Award and Grants Compliance:   	The primary functions of the post-award side are to coordinate, review, negotiate and accept grant awards.  The office initiates the establishment of grant accounts following PI notification.  The office works with faculty, beginning with a one-on-one orientation session to review the terms of the grant, federal regulations and institutional requirements.  If awards require modification, the post-award office will work with them and the granting agency to secure the extention/change.  The office also works with Deans and PIs to ensure that reporting milestones are met.  Throughout the life of the award, the post-award office provides technical support for award management through close-out. 	We have added the role of grants policies and compliance to this group.  Their role is to create standard policies and guidelines where we currently have none.  We found that in several cases, DePaul has no policies to address basic grants issues and each time a problem or question arises, it is handled as a brand new event.  We are working with different academic units, OGC as well as restricted accounting to develop policies and guidelines.  This group is also responsible for the regular review of policies that relate to ORS (e.g. conflict of interest, scientific misconduct, etc.).  Finally, this group has been active in creating training modules to familiarize faculty, staff and students with specific procedures as they relate to funding.Research Protections Group  	The Office of Research Protections (ORP) supports three committees that review and approve research and other activities at DePaul University; 1) The Institutional Review Board (IRB), 2) Institutional Animal Care and Use Committee (IACUC), and 3) Institutional Biosafety Committee (IBC). The IRB is responsible for reviewing research involving human subjects conducted at DePaul or by DePaul faculty, staff, or students. The IACUC is responsible for ensuring the proper care and humane treatment of vertebrate animals used in research and educational activities at DePaul University. The IBC is responsible for ensuring the safe acquisition, use, and disposal of all biohazardous agents at DePaul University, particularly procedures or techniques that involve recombinant DNA, Center for Disease Control (CDC) designated Select Agents, or potentially infectious materials, such as human blood. The Office of Research Protections provides administrative support for the three committees and ensures that DePaul University, as an institution, is compliant with the federal regulations and guidance that pertain to these three committees.

Among others, available documents in the startupPerColator include a Certificate of Incorporation, Bylaws, Action by Written Consent of the Sole Incorporator, Action by Unanimous Written Consent in Lieu of the Organizational Meeting of the Board of Directors and an Action by Written Consent of the Stockholders. To aid founders in pursuit of funding, startupPerColator also offers users access to a free customizable term sheet generator that the firm developed based on National Venture Capital Association (NVCA) model documents.

name: Meyer Law
html_description: Our lawyers are top-notch, highly experienced leaders and have a solid understanding of the various issues that domestic and international businesses deal with on a daily basis. We are entrepreneurial-minded and passionate about helping businesses. We love what we do and that’s what drives us. Businesses shouldn’t have to pay exorbitant legal fees for high quality legal services. In today’s economy, most businesses are trying to reduce costs, but still need the same amount of work to be done. We provide real legal solutions. We offer affordable rates for savvy businesses that know that traditional law firm fees are not practical and not your only option. We won’t nickel and dime you, nor will we train inexperienced associates at your expense. Our clients appreciate how transparent we are with our billing practices. Whether you’re a start-up, a small business gaining traction, a fast growing mid-sized company or a large corporation, we can help you. Our Practice Areas are diverse and no project is too big or too small. Regardless of your size, you’ll never feel like a small fish in a big pond. We value all of our relationships equally.

The Peoria Area Chamber of Commerce is a membership organization of area businesses, delivering value to its members by cultivating a thriving business community, presenting the united voice of local business to government, offering continuously upgraded products and services for business enhancement and providing strategic business advisory services.

 The Peoria Area Chamber of Commerce’s Board of Directors approved a comprehensive strategic plan. The plan is designed to provide a roadmap for the Chamber’s ultimate goals of becoming the leading voice for business in the region. The plan’s guiding principles are outlined below.

The Peoria Area Chamber of Commerce is the leading voice and resource for business in the region.

  • The leading voice for business in the region through political advocacy.
  • Inclusive and diverse in the approach to our work.
  • An advocate to improve the quality of place in the region.
  • A source for strong leadership development.

name: Chicago Innovation Mentors
html_description: Chicago Innovation Mentors (CIM) is a consortium of the University of Chicago, University of Illinois, Northwestern University, PROPEL, and Argonne National Laboratory. CIM's mission is to support university-based and local new technology innovation ventures through the use of mentor teams. CIM works with each science-based mentee venture to encourage innovation, catalyze tech commercialization, strengthen the ecosystem necessary to support entrepreneurs, enhance local economic development, and embrace risk taking. CIM is setting the stage for long term growth in Chicago-based entrepreneurship, innovation and commercialization. There are no fees associated with the Chicago Innovation Mentors program for mentors or mentees. That being said, you must go through the CIM application process in order to be selected as a mentor. All mentees must have ties to one of the participating universities or PROPEL. If you are interested in participating in CIM as a Mentor or Mentee, and meet our qualifications, please contact our Operations Manager, Martha Wade.

name: Illinois Technology Association
html_description: The Illinois Technology Association (ITA) is a membership-based organization that prides itself on being a driving force behind the advancement of Illinois' vibrant technology industry. Providing programs and services focused on development, visibility and talent attraction, ITA’s mission is focused on growth acceleration of technology companies across the state. Consisting of more than 700 member companies and a network of 50,000 individuals, ITA members benefit from access to programs in three key areas: Development, Talent, and Visibility. Through these programs, ITA brings growth-stage industry companies together, leveraging the connections and experiences of the community to increase the overall success rate of the local industry. ITA provides the tools our members need to address the strategic and operational aspects of their businesses. Members include growth-stage companies in software and software services, mobile, internet, IT consulting, gaming, online services, electronics and telecommunications. Members find deep value in collaboration and collective action that far exceeds the annual cost of membership. Together, the Illinois Technology Association (ITA) is a driving force behind the growth of Illinois' vibrant technology industry. ITA membership is required to access all of the benefits of the association. Membership is fee-based at the company level, and although we do offer access to the General Public on some events/programs, there are fees associated and limited space available.

We’ve done this by providing businesses with the resources needed to solve business-related problems and take advantage of new opportunities. We have helped more than 200 companies obtain loans in excess of more than $40 million to start or expand their businesses, which have created or retained more than 3,400 jobs. This location also houses a Procurement Technical Assistance Center (PTAC), which provides one-on-one counseling, technical information, marketing assistance and training to existing businesses that are interested in selling their products and/or services to local, state, or federal government agencies, as well as an International Trade Center (ITC), which provides information, counseling and training to existing, new to-export companies interested in pursuing international trade opportunities.

We've done this by providing businesses with the resources needed to solve business-related problems and take advantage of new opportunities. We have assisted over 200 companies obtain loans in excess of $2.8 million to start or expand their businesses, which have created or retained more than 1,300 jobs. This location also houses a Procurement Technical Assistance Center (PTAC), which provides one-on-one counseling, technical information, marketing assistance and training to existing businesses that are interested in selling their products and/or services to local, state, or federal government agencies, as well as an International Trade Center (ITC), which provides information, counseling and training to existing, new to-export companies interested in pursuing international trade opportunities.

html_description: We know that by helping small businesses launch, expand and improve their profitability, we’re also helping them create jobs in the Chicago area. And that helps everyone. That’s why we offer support and educational training programs for all entrepreneurs, including veterans, ex-offenders and even home-based businesses. Our clients are adults in the Chicago area who are starting up a new business or expanding their existing one. We specialize in making low cost business loans to eligible small businesses in the Chicago area that cannot access loan funds through traditional lending channels. We provide one-on-one business advice at no charge for existing and start-up small businesses. We offer entrepreneurial training, business assistance, mentoring and access to capital.

The Illinois SBDC at UIC works closely with students, faculty and the community to assist entrepreneurs with market analysis, business planning, securing business loans, and obtaining outside equity investment.

Funding from a CAP can be used for many business purposes, including start-up costs, working capital, business procurement, franchise fees, equipment, and inventory.

DCEO seeks to encourage new bank lending to small business, by purchasing portions of bank term loans, and RLOCs, applying below market interest rates to DCEO’s portion, and subordinating its exposure that those of the lending entities.

The program supplies pledged collateral accounts to participating lending institutions. This program enhances the collateral of individual loans, while providing a source of deposits to lending institutions.

name: Community Service Block Grant Loan Program
resource_name: Community Service Block Grant Loan Program
html_description: The CSBG Loan Program is administered jointly by the Illinois Department of Commerce and Economic Opportunity (DCEO), statewide Community Action Agencies (CAAs) and Illinois Ventures for Community Action (IVCA). The Program provides long-term, fixed-rate financing to new or expanding small businesses in exchange for job creation and employment for low-income individuals. CSBG funds usually make up between 20-49% of the entire loan project and have a low interest rate of 5% to 7.5%.

name: Emerging Technological Enterprises Grant Program
html_description: The goal of the Emerging Technological Enterprises Program is to provide grants, loans, and other investments to emerging technology enterprises to support and encourage: (i) commercialization of technology based products and services; (ii) technology transfer projects involving the promotion of new or innovative technologies; or (iii) research and development projects to respond to unique, advanced technology projects and which foster the development of Illinois’ economy through the advancement of the State’s economic, scientific, and technological assets. Projects should indicate a significant potential benefit to the state’s economy. Criteria for evaluation includes the relationship of the proposed project to the State’s future economic growth. Projects should spur new advances in other Illinois companies and should indicate a significant potential benefit to the state’s economy. The purpose of the program is to foster economic development and increased employment in Illinois. Eligible activities include: acquiring real properties for industrial or commercial site development; acquiring, rehabilitating and reconveying industrial and commercial properties for the purpose of expanding employment and encouraging private and other public sector investment in the economy of Illinois. Questions and requests pertaining to this program should be directed to Pam Giroux at the Illinois Department of Commerce and Economic Opportunity.
institution_name: Illinois Department of Commerce and Economic Opportunity

name: General Small Business Loan Program
html_description: The general small business, or 7(a) loan program is the SBA's primary business loan program. It is the agency's most frequently used financial assistance program because of its flexibility in loan structure, variety of loan proceed uses, and availability. The program has broad eligibility requirements and credit criteria to accommodate a wide range of financing needs. The business loans that SBA guarantees do not come from the agency, but rather from banks and other approved lenders.The loans are funded by these organizations, and they make the decisions to approve or not approve the applicants' requests. The SBA guaranty reduces the lender's risk of borrower non-payment. If the borrower defaults, the lender can request SBA to pay the lender that percentage of the outstanding balance guaranteed by SBA. This allows the lender to recover a portion from SBA of what it lent if the borrower can't make the payments.The borrower is still obligated for the full amount. To qualify for an SBA loan, a small business must meet the lender's criteria and the 7(a) requirements. In addition, the lender must certify that it would not provide this loan under the proposed terms and conditions unless it can obtain an SBA guaranty. If the SBA is going to provide a lender with a guaranty, the applicant must be eligible and creditworthy and the loan structured under conditions acceptable to SBA.
sectors_facet: Clean Tech/Alternative Energy, Food/Agriculture, IT/Digital/Web-Mobile, Manufacturing, Biotech and Life Sciences, Healthcare and Medical Devices, Nanotechnology, Transportation/Logistics, Social/Impact Venture, Telecommunications

name: Microloan Program
html_description: The Microloan Program provides small, short-term loans to small business concerns and certain types of not-for-profit child-care centers. The SBA makes funds available to specially designated intermediary lenders, which are nonprofit community-based organizations with experience in lending as well as management and technical assistance. These intermediaries make loans to eligible borrowers. The maximum loan amount is $50,000, but the average microloan is about $13,000.

name: CDC/504 Loan Program
html_description: The SBA 504 Loan program is a powerful economic development loan program that offers small businesses another avenue for business financing, while promoting business growth, and job creation. As of February 15, 2012, the $50 Billion in 504 loans has created over 2 million jobs. This program is a proven success and win-win-win for the small business, the community and participating lenders. The 504 Loan Program provides approved small businesses with long-term, fixed-rate financing used to acquire fixed assets for expansion or modernization. 504 loans are made available through Certified Development Companies (CDCs), SBA's community based partners for providing 504 Loans.

name: Small Business Innovation Research Program
html_description: The Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) program is a highly competitive program that encourages domestic small businesses to engage in Federal Research/Research and Development (R/R&D) that has the potential for commercialization. Through a competitive awards-based program, SBIR enables small businesses to explore their technological potential and provides the incentive to profit from its commercialization. By including qualified small businesses in the nation's R&D arena, high-tech innovation is stimulated and the United States gains entrepreneurial spirit as it meets its specific research and development needs.
sectors_facet: Clean Tech/Alternative Energy, Food/Agriculture, IT/Digital/Web-Mobile, Manufacturing, Biotech and Life Sciences, Healthcare and Medical Devices, Nanotechnology, Transportation/Logistics, Social/Impact Venture, Telecommunications

name: Small Business Technology Transfer Program
html_description: Small Business Technology Transfer (STTR) is another program that expands funding opportunities in the federal innovation research and development (R&D) arena. Central to the program is expansion of the public/private sector partnership to include the joint venture opportunities for small businesses and nonprofit research institutions. The unique feature of the STTR program is the requirement for the small business to formally collaborate with a research institution in Phase I and Phase II. STTR's most important role is to bridge the gap between performance of basic science and commercialization of resulting innovations.
sectors_facet: Clean Tech/Alternative Energy, Food/Agriculture, IT/Digital/Web-Mobile, Manufacturing, Biotech and Life Sciences, Healthcare and Medical Devices, Nanotechnology, Transportation/Logistics, Social/Impact Venture, Telecommunications

name: SBIR Technical Assistance Program
html_description: EnterpriseWorks offers SBIR and STTR technical assistance and counseling through the support of the EDA funded East Central Illinois University Center. The Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) and Small Business Technology Transfer (STTR) programs provide qualified small businesses, with opportunities to propose innovative projects that meet specific federal needs. The EnterprsieWorks SBIR technical assistance program encourages entrepreneurs to apply for federal grants. We offer free guidance to small businesses interested in submitting proposals to participating agencies in response to agency solicitations. We also offer training two times a year on the overall SBIR and STTR program and shorter workshops with specific topic areas pertaining to SBIR funding. Let us help you become familiar with SBIR funding, search solicitations, learn best practices for applications, talk with program managers for input, draft a budget, write a commercialization plan, or execute an award agreement.Its a free service to help entrepreneurs in East Central Illinois that are potential awardees for SBIR and STTR funding.

Our goal is to stimulate new initiatives and ventures, create new connections and collaborations, and establish a community of people who have the desire to achieve great things.

name: Chicago Innovation Awards
html_description: Established in 2002, the Chicago Innovation Awards shine a bright light on the creative spirit of Chicago by focusing attention on the most significant new products and services introduced in the region. The winners each year are innovations that uniquely fill unmet needs, spark a competitive response in the marketplace, exceed market expectations, achieve financial success, and improve people’s lives. They emerge from the public, private, and nonprofit sectors. Most importantly, the Chicago Innovation Awards remind us that innovation is thriving in America’s heartland. The Chicago Innovation Awards has grown to be much more than just an award ceremony. Through many events over the course of the year, the Chicago Innovation Awards not only recognize nominees and winners, but also provide valuable connections through business networking and development opportunities, as well as teaching on best innovation practices through mentoring, scholarship, panel discussions, and education courses. It is free to nominate a new product or service for the Chicago Innovation Awards. There is a nominal fee to attend our events throughout the year. Every sector, organization, and industry in the Chicago region can participate in our program.
